719891f-a.title: Manhattan: Franklin Street - Varick Street
719891f-a.text:
126-128 Franklin Street, north side, at the convergance of Varick
Street and West Broadway. Note the Franklin Street Station of the Sitth
Ave., Elevated on West Broadway.
About 1920.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
719891f-a.folder: Franklin Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

719890f-a.title: Manhattan: Franklin Street - Varick Street
719890f-a.text:
126-128 Franklin Street, north side, at the convergance of Varick
Street and West Broadway, as seen from across Finn Square. Note the Franklin
Street Station of the Sixth Ave., Elevated on West Broadway. Building o'er
tonering said station, is the new Telephone Building.
April 2, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
719890f-a.folder: Franklin Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

724379f-a.title: Manhattan: West Broadway - Franklin Street
724379f-a.text:
West Broadway, at the 3. W. corner of Franklin ttreet
(right), viewing across the open area identified as Finn
Square, formed at the point of convergence by West Broadway
and Varick Street. Ordinarily this location would be a
pottion of the latter thoroughfare, as it is apparently a
continuation. The fact remains that both sides of the
Square are classified as being West Broadway.
A one story tax-payer (No. 137 Franklin Street) is
shown upon the former site of the Fifth Ward Museum. This
was operated by an individual named "Riley". On exhibition
there, included with other incunabula was the statue of
William Pitt. Tho New York Historical Society posseses same
today.
The New York Sun published a drawing of the old Hotel
building in their series "O1d New York in Pictures". This
was No. 169, titled, 'Tho Fifth Ward Museum Hotel in 1864'.
The large building bearing the various signs is No. 139
Franklin Street, and adjoins the corner.
724379f-a.folder: West Broadway & Franklin Street, Manhattan, NY

724380f-a.title: Manhattan: West Broadway - Franklin Street
724380f-a.text:
West Broadway, at Finn Square, showing buildings
on the east side, extending from Franklin (right, not
seen) to White Street's. The 2A-story structure appear-
ing at the left is at the N.W. corner of the latter
thoroughfare, being No. 2 White Street. O'ershadowing
same is the utilitarfan New York Telephone Building at
the convergence of Sixth Avenue South and Church Street.
Shown is the entrance to the west side line of
the I.R.T. subway which runs along Varick Street.
May 19, 1939
P. L. Sperr
724380f-a.folder: West Broadway & Franklin Street, Manhattan, NY
